html:
Latin numbers (edit)
M
1,000
100
    Cardinal: mīlle
    Ordinal: mīllēsimus
    Adverbial: mīlliēns, mīlliēs
    Distributive: mīllenī
Latin Wikipedia has an article on:
mille
Wikipedia la

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈmiːl.le/, [ˈmiːl.lʲɛ]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈmil.le/, [ˈmil.lɛ]
  • Audio (Classical)
    		(file)

Etymology 1[edit]

From Proto-Italic *smīɣeslī, from Proto-Indo-European *smih₂ǵʰéslih₂ (“one thousand”), from *ǵʰes- (“hand”) (whence also hir, Ancient Greek χείρ (kheír)), as if “full hand”.[1] Cognates include Ancient Greek χίλιοι (khílioi), Persian هزار‎ (hezar), and Sanskrit सहस्र (sahásra).

Alternative forms[edit]

  • Symbol: M or ↀ

Numeral[edit]

mīlle (genitive mīlle); semi-indeclinable numeral

  1. thousand; 1000
    • 405, Jerome and others, Vulgate, Ezras 1:9
      Et hic est numerus eorum: fialae aureae triginta, fialae argenteae mille, cultri viginti novem, scyphi aurei triginta.
      And this is their number: thirty gold fialae, a thousand silver fialae, twenty-nine knives, thirty gold cups.
Usage notes[edit]

The singular form behaves as an indeclinable adjective, but the plural behaves as a declinable neuter noun of the third declension. See Appendix:Latin cardinal numerals for additional information.

Declension[edit]

Semi-indeclinable numeral.

Case / Gender Masc./Fem./Neut. Masc./Fem./Neut.

mīllium

mīllia

mīllibus

mīllia

  • mīlle passuum
Related terms[edit]

  • mīllēnārius

    • Aragonese: mil
  • Old French: mile, mil

    • Galician: mil
    • Portuguese: mil

  • Old Spanish: mil, mill,
    • Spanish: mil
      • → Navajo: mííl

  • Romanian: mie
  • Romansch: milli
  • Sardinian: mila, milli
  • Sicilian: milli, middi
  • → Albanian: mijë

  • → West Germanic: *mīliju (see there for further descendants)

See also[edit]
  • Appendix:Latin cardinal numerals

Etymology 2[edit]

Shortened from Latin mīlle passūs, mīlle passuum (“Roman mile”, literally “a thousand of paces”).

Noun[edit]

mīlle n

  1. mile, particularly a Roman mile of 8 stades (stadia); 1,000 paces (passūs); or 5,000 feet (pedes)
Declension[edit]

Semi-indeclinable numeral.

Descendants[edit]
  • Italian: miglio
  • Old French:
    • French: mille
    • Norman: mille
  • Sardinian: miza
  • Spanish: milla
  • → Ancient Greek: μίλιον (mílion), μείλιον (meílion), μίλιν (mílin)
    • Greek: μίλι (míli)
    • → Hebrew: מַיְל‎‎ (mayl)
    • → Old Armenian: մղոն (młon), միլոն (milon), մողոն (mołon)
      • Armenian: մղոն (młon)
  • → Aramaic: [script needed] (mīlā), [script needed] (mīl)
    • Classical Syriac: ܡܝܠܐ‎ (mīlā), ܡܝܠ‎ (mīl)
    • → Arabic: ميل‎ (mīl)
      • → Middle Armenian: միլ (mil)
      • → Ottoman Turkish: مِیل‎ (mīl)
        • Turkish: mil
      • → Persian: مِیل‎ (mīl)
  • → Old Irish: míle
    • Middle Irish: míle
      • Irish: míle
      • Manx: milley
      • Scottish Gaelic: mìle

    • to be fined 10,000 asses: decem milibus aeris damnari
